title: How to Thicken Sauce with Flour

steps.title: Mix a little flour and water in a bowl.
steps.content: Mix a little flour and water in a bowl. Use 2 tablespoons (about 16-18 grams) of flour and .25 cups (59 mL) of water for every 1 cup (240 mL) of sauce. Mix the water and flour carefully, making sure that there are no lumps. [1] X Research source Be sure to use cold water, since warm or hot water will cause the flour to clump together. If you want a thicker sauce, add a little more flour. Use less flour for a thinner sauce.

steps.title: Stir the flour and water combination into your sauce.
steps.content: Stir the flour and water combination into your sauce. Once the flour and water are thoroughly mixed, slowly pour this mixture (called a slurry) into the sauce. [2] X Research source Keep stirring or whisking as you pour to prevent clumps from forming. [3] X Research source Make sure the slurry is thoroughly mixed into the sauce to create an even thickness.

steps.title: Cook the sauce over medium heat until it thickens.
steps.content: Cook the sauce over medium heat until it thickens. After mixing in the slurry, allow the sauce to cook until it becomes bubbly. You should also notice the sauce becoming thicker. Keep stirring as the sauce continues to cook to prevent burning. [4] X Research source The sauce will thicken a little more after it cools, so aim for getting it just shy of how thick you want it. You may need to experiment a bit to achieve the texture you want.

steps.title: Let the sauce cook 1 more minute after it thickens.
steps.content: Let the sauce cook 1 more minute after it thickens. Keep checking the sauce as it cooks to see if it has achieved the desired thickness. After that, give it an additional minute to cook before taking it off the heat. This will give the flour time to cook thoroughly so that your sauce doesn’t have a strong raw flour flavor. [5] X Research source Allowing the sauce to reach a full boil after adding the slurry can also help cook off the flour flavor. [6] X Research source Take care not to let your sauce burn, however!

steps.title: Choose a fat that’s right for your roux.
steps.content: Choose a fat that’s right for your roux. The type of fat you choose will affect the flavor and texture of your sauce, so take this into account before you start cooking. The common options include: [7] X Research source Butter, for a rich and creamy flavor. This is a good choice for cream-based sauces, like béchamel or alfredo. Animal fat, such as bacon or pork drippings. This will impart a meaty or sausage-like flavor, so choose this option for gumbos and other Creole dishes. Vegetable oil. This is the most neutral option, flavor-wise. It’s also less likely to burn than butter-based roux and is a vegan-friendly choice.

steps.title: Mix together equal parts flour and fat in a saucepan.
steps.content: Mix together equal parts flour and fat in a saucepan. Use 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of fat and 2 tablespoons (about 16-18 grams) of flour for every 1 cup (240 mL) of sauce, or a little more flour for a thicker sauce. Stir the fat and flour together with a long-handled wooden spoon until they are thoroughly combined. [8] X Research source If you’re using a hard fat, like butter, melt it in the pan first and then stir the butter in.

steps.title: Cook the mixture over medium-low heat, stirring constantly.
steps.content: Cook the mixture over medium-low heat, stirring constantly. Once you’ve mixed your ingredients together, begin cooking the roux. You will need to keep stirring in order to prevent the roux from burning. [9] X Research source It’s especially easy to scorch butter-based roux, so keep a close eye on your pot as you cook. You can ensure even cooking by stirring in a figure-8 pattern. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Let the roux cook until it reaches the desired color.
steps.content: Let the roux cook until it reaches the desired color. The longer you cook your roux, the darker it will become. Darker roux has a more toasty and complex flavor, but it is also less effective at thickening than a lighter roux. [11] X Research source Cook for 3-5 minutes for a light roux, which is good for sauces like béchamel or white gravy. [12] X Research source A light roux should be cooked enough to lose the characteristic raw flour taste and smell, but not long enough that it begins to brown. For brown roux, cook for 6-7 minutes. This is an ideal roux for brown gravy. [13] X Research source If you want dark roux, let your mixture cook for 8-15 minutes. This is a good option for Cajun and Creole sauces. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the roux to cool before combining it with your sauce.
steps.content: Allow the roux to cool before combining it with your sauce. When your roux is cooked to the desired color, remove it from the heat and let it sit for a while. You can use it once it is warm to the touch (as opposed to hot) or even refrigerate it and use it cold. [15] X Research source If you add the roux to a cooler sauce while it is still bubbling hot, it will break apart and form clumps. As a general rule, it’s best to combine roux and the rest of your sauce when they are at similar temperatures. For example, if haven’t started heating your sauce yet, add the roux while both are cold or lukewarm.

steps.title: Whisk the roux into your sauce and let it simmer for at least 20 minutes.
steps.content: Whisk the roux into your sauce and let it simmer for at least 20 minutes. Once your roux is cooled, stir it gradually into your sauce. Make sure to mix it thoroughly so that the sauce thickens evenly. Allow the mixture to simmer for 20 minutes or longer so that any residual flour flavor is cooked out. [16] X Research source During the simmering process, fat or oil may rise to the top of the sauce. Use a spoon to skim it off.
